ray.rage.scene.controllers

Class WaypointController

  • java.lang.Object
    • ray.rage.scene.controllers.AbstractController
      • ray.rage.scene.controllers.WaypointController
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Disposable, Node.Controller

    public class WaypointController
extends AbstractController
    A Node.Controller implementation that uses linear interpolation (i.e. LERP) to move nodes along a sequence of positions, in world-space, as a function of time. After the last waypoint has been reached, the cycle is restarted.

    Note that LERP does not produce constant-speed motion. Rather, the speed of movement is determined by the distance between the waypoints under consideration, based on time restrictions.

    For example, suppose this controller only has 15 seconds to move a node between two positions, A and B. The greater the distance between them, the faster the nodes will be moved to ensure they arrive at their destination within the specified time frame.

    To keep movement speed roughly "constant" between waypoints, the client must make sure to either keep waypoints at roughly equal distances from each other, or use different time values.

    A minimum of 2 waypoints are required for this controller to work.

    Author:
    Raymond L. Rivera

      • notifyDispose

        public void notifyDispose()
        Description copied from interface: Disposable
        Explicitly releases the internal resources held by this instance, making it unusable afterwards.

        WARNING: This method is meant to be used internally by the framework and not by game clients. Use directly only if you really know what you're doing.
